Half-life ha dato un enorme scossone al mondo videoludico e alla concorrenza dell'epoca.
Un titolo dal gameplay innovativo, divertente e curato. Una grafica al tempo impressionante, faceva da contorno ad un level design con i controfiocchi, ricco di variet√† e di spunti interessanti che portavano il giocatore a valutare al meglio l'ambiente di gioco prima di intervenire.
L'unico vero neo di questa produzione magistrale, sta nella trama.
L'idea della narrazione in prima persona, senza scene d'intermezzo, avrebbe potuto anche funzionare, se non fosse stato per la quasi assoluta mancanza di un substrato solido che dia un senso a tutta l'azione.
Si sa ci√≤ che sta accadendo, sia ci√≤ che bisogna fare, tuttavia il perch√© di molte cose resta celato, tutto viene affidato a qualche frase degli NPC e all'immaginazione del giocatore e, inoltre, il finale poco appagante di certo non migliora un quadro complessivo che, sul piano meramente narrativo, aveva potenzialit√† infinite che sono state sfruttate solo in minima parte.
Nonostante ci√≤ il gioco rapisce per ore il giocatore, senza mai momenti di noia o cadute di stile, instillando continuamente il bisogno di andare avanti e scoprire quali situazioni dovranno esser affrontate nelle aree successive.
Un goal in termini di gameplay, atmosfera, longevit√† e innovazione, un palo per quanto riguarda la narrazione.
In ogni caso, i complimenti a Valve sono doverosi!

Spero che Valve la smetta di fare sciocchezze da circo con tech demo VR e si metta a lavorare al pi√π che meritato terzo capitolo.

Holy damn I love this game.
You probably already knew that its a great game but to me there is something special about it.

*Note* I won't be going into plot details so there aren't any big spoilers.

First of all I really love the graphics of this game. I've heard people say that the Gold Source Engine hasn't aged too well but I personally think it has. It somehow looks both basic and complex at the same time, like the Tau Cannon's practical design. Unlike Half Life 2 this game is quite colourful and bright despite the fact that the appocalypse is happening, which makes the game seem very charming to me.

Secondly, the gameplay has a mixture of puzzle solving, story telling and action, none of which get tiring. The physics of pushing boxes may be a bit weird but its not that bad. Speaking of action, the weapons and character design are all off the charts. The enemies from Xen are all very alien looking and amazing, such as the Houndeyes with their sonic shockwave attacks, and the terrifying Tentacle creature that genuinely terrified me on my first playthrough. Xen itself is very impressive and surreal, especially for a 3d game from late 1998.
The game doesn't have any NPCs that stick around the main character, Gordon Freeman, and usually they die due to their quite bad AI. The NPCs can also glitch out or scream for no reason, which is quite funny to experience. Some of the voice acting is kind of underwhelming, and the characters can have bizzare conversations such as 'Achoo! Kindly lower your voice'. Also the security guards can accidentally kill you. That's annoying.

There are many secrets hidden all over the Black Mesa Compound, and many amazing weapons to find, like the alien Hivehand and the Gluon Gun which fires a disintegrating laser. The combat is also very good, and every enemy has a weapon they are weak against for you to experiment with.

Without a doubt this is one of my favouite video games ever, and for the price of ¬£7.99 or $10.60, I really think you should play it if you haven't before.

Just finally got a chance to complete this masterpiece. I'm amazed to the attention of depth and detail especially with level design and detail to puzzle solving and enviroment interaction. Of course its no surprise.  I did complete Half life 2 and the Episodes that followed, which had the same level of care and expectations. You play as a scientist, slash badass named Gordon Freeman who's here to save us all from a crazy under world that have broken in to our during an experiment you have your trusty crowbar and a large assortment of weapons at your disposal to handle these pest and Combine troops. These weapons are half the enjoyment the other being the enviroments and level design, where you have to solve and create enviromental changes or explore to get through. Each level has an adventure element tide to it and never felt like a chour to get through. I honestly could not stop playing even through the difficult stages later in the game. The sense of accomplishment was well felt. And the ending is a Great Fire work show ( Yes Pun intended) and a awesome ending to such a fantastic gaming experience.

The first Half Life game in the series. Shoot zombies, gawk at those weird little headcrabs, accidentally fall into vats of acid, and much more! On a more serious note, this is an amazing game. The story alone makes this game one of the best. it's cheap fun, like a Ford Fiesta!
Really cool techno soundtrack, I'm always having a fight over if HL2 is better than this or not.
My personal favourite single player first person shooter game. The beginning of a good game series. Gordon Freeman is my favourite video game protagonist and hero.

Played it to see how it fared to the sequel; better than I expected, and I got a glimpse of an early time for first-person shooters. Would recommend if you're looking for an action game that's, for the most part, [i] detached from a storyline and keeps things on the action [/i]. It's from a time where, instead of inserting some cutscene or dialogue sit-through, the game just paces the action by having some moments of downtime. 

[b] You progress by shooting, shooting a little less, and then shooting even more (with some puzzles in between). [/b]

That isn't to say that's all there is, though. There's a fair bit of atmosphere in the background. The soundtrack, while [i] very sparse [/i], opts to place short music cues to establish a mood and leave you in silence thereafter. It may range from framing the eerieness of a just-occurred massacre, to starting off the rush of a firefight, and then to allowing you to bask in the glory of whatever you had just accomplished. I'd see myself reloading a quicksave just to experience one of those moments again.

To go back to the shooting part, I'll say the game might feel a little aged if you're used to modern gunplay conventions. There's no aiming down sights; it's run out of cover, find the nearest threat, and shoot them dead with whatever weapon you deem appropriate. The only feedback you get is the enemy dropping once they can't soak any more damage. It's a bit of a novel thing, but I liked how it felt.

I think the one thing I'd recommend to whoever chooses to play it would be to [u] not abuse quicksaves too much [/u]. There's this certain [i] primal [/i] feeling you get from surviving from the skin of your teeth. As long as you're not playing on hard difficulty, you can probably survive more endeavors than you think. I wish I gave myself this advice earlier in my playthrough, feel like I would've had more fun with more blood pumping.

That's all I've got to say on it. Definitely worth the $10 [i] (or even less at during whatever insane Steam sale) [/i].
